facts.text: Messrs. Jullunder Vegetables Syndicate was a firm doing business in Jullunder from October 4, 1952 to July 11, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Jullunder Vegetables Syndicate was a firm doing business in Jullunder from October 4, 1952 to July 11, 1953. It was dissolved on July 11, 1953.

facts.text: The firm was dissolved on July 11, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It was dissolved on July 11, 1953. An intimation of the dissolution of the firm under S. 16 of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948, hereinafter

facts.text: Intimation of the dissolution of the firm under S. 16 of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948, was sent to the Department on July 18, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: An intimation of the dissolution of the firm under S. 16 of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948, hereinafter called the Act, was sent to the Department on July 18, 1953.

facts.text: The firm was assessed to sales-tax on May 30, 1953, by the Sales-tax Officer for the period between October 4, 1952 and March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was assessed to sales-tax on May 30, 1953, by the Sales-tax Officer under the provisions of the Act in respect of its turnover for the period between October 4, 1952 and March 31, 1953 but the said

facts.text: The assessment order dated May 30, 1953 was quashed on April 11, 1955, by the Financial Commissioner on the ground that the authority had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: but the said assessment order was quashed on April 11, 1955, by the Financial Commissioner on the ground that the authority which made the assessment had numberjurisdiction to do so.

facts.text: On September 3, 1955, the Sales-tax Officer made a fresh assessment on the turnover of the firm, fixing taxable turnover at Rs. 15,04,091-11-3 and tax at Rs. 47,002-14-0.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1955, the Sales-tax Officer made a fresh assessment on the turnover of the said firm. Its taxable turnover was fixed at Rs. 15,04,091-11-3 and was assessed to sales-tax in a sum of Rs. 47,002-14-0.

facts.text: It is not clear from the record whether after the order of the Financial Commissioner fresh proceedings were initiated or the earlier proceedings were continued.

anchor.surface_text: It is number clear from the record whether after the order of the Financial Commissioner fresh proceedings were initiated by the Sales-tax Officer or whether the earlier proceedings initiated by him before the dissolution of the firm were companytinued thereafter.

facts.text: The question formulated for the Full Bench assumes that the firm was dissolved before the proceedings for assessment were initiated.

anchor.surface_text: But from the question formulated for the decision of the Full Bench of the High Court, which is the subject-matter of this appeal, it appears that the firm was dissolved before the proceedings for the assessment were initiated.

facts.text: On appeal, the Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner by order dated October 20, 1956 reduced the tax payable to Rs. 30,049-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner, by his order dated October 20, 1956, reduced the figure of turnover and also companyrespondingly reduced the tax payable to a sum of Rs. 30,049-12-0.

facts.text: On revision, the Financial Commissioner rejected the contention that assessment proceedings could not be taken against a dissolved firm and confirmed the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On revision, the Financial Commissioner, rejecting the companytention of the firm that the assessment proceedings companyld number be taken against a firm after its dissolution, companyfirmed the assess- 4 5 9 ment.

facts.text: State of Punjab preferred appeal to Supreme Court on certificate issued by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Punjab, on a certificate issued by the High Court, has preferred the present appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate issued by the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh raises the question whether a firm companyld be assessed to sales-tax after it was dissolved. The facts may briefly be stated.

issues.text: Whether a partnership firm, which is a registered firm under the provisions of the Punjab Sales Tax Act and which was in existence throughout the period for which assessment of sales tax has to be made, ceased to be liable to the said assessment by the mere fact that it has dissolved before the proceedings for assessment are initiated.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the following question was referred to the High Court for its decision under S. 22 of the Act Whether a partnership firm, which is a registered firm under the provisions of the Punjab Sales Tax Act and which was in existence throughout the period for which assessment of sales tax has to be made, ceased to be liable to the said assessment by the mere fact that it has dissolved before the proceedings for assessment are initiated.

issues.text: the question of the statutory right of a taxing authority under the provisions of the Act to assess a dissolved firm in respect of its pre-dissolution turnover

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the question of the statutory right of a taxing authority under the provisions of the Act to assess a dissolved firm in respect of its pre- dissolution turnover. That question falls to be decided on the relevant provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: firm is separate assessable entity under Act per S.2(d)

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether a firm is a separate assessable entity for the purposes of the Act or whether it is only a compendious term used to denote a group of partners. ... If we read the expression firm in substitution of the word dealer, it will be apparent that a firm is an independent assessable unit for the purposes of the Act.

arguments.claim: dissolved firm cannot be assessed without statutory provision as it ceases legal entity

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 3 of the Income-tax Act firm is treated as a unit of assessment and as a distinct assessable entity. ... If that be so, on dissolution, the firm ceases to be a legal entity. Thereafter, on principle, unless there is a statutory provision permitting the assessment of a dissolved firm, there is no longer any scope for assessing the firm which ceased to have a legal existence.

arguments.claim: no distinction between assessment proceedings initiated before or after dissolution

anchor.surface_text: Further, we cannot discover any distinction in the matter of assessability of a dissolved firm between a case where the proceedings were initiated before and that after the said dissolution.

arguments.claim: S.16 requires notice of discontinuation for administrative purposes only, does not permit assessment of dissolved firm

anchor.surface_text: Section 16, so far as is relevant to the present enquiry, only says that if a dealer discontinues his business, it shall within the prescribed time inform the prescribed authority accordingly. This section does not expressly state that a dealer, if it happens to be a firm, continues to have legal existence even if it has ceased to be a firm.

arguments.claim: Rule 40 imposes joint liability for payment but not for assessment of dissolved firm

anchor.surface_text: Nor does r. 40 of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Rules, 1949, carry the matter further. It only imposes a joint and several liability on the dealer and its partners for the payment of tax penalty or any amount due under the Act or the rules.

arguments.claim: Income-tax Act S.44 expressly provides machinery for assessing discontinued firms, unlike this Act

anchor.surface_text: This Court in C. A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam 1 , speaking through Shah, J., held that S. 44 of the Income-tax Act set up a machinery for assessing the tax liability of firms which have discontinued their business.

arguments.claim: various High Court decisions sustaining post-dissolution assessments are incorrect as they confuse assessment power with partners' payment liability

anchor.surface_text: All these decisions... were overburdened with the consequences of a contrary construction on the incidence of taxation and also by their mixing up the question of the statutory power of assessing a dissolved firm with the liability of the partners thereof to pay the tax so assessed on the firm before dissolution.

holdings.text: As in the present case, the firm was dissolved before the order of assessment was made, the said order was bad.

anchor.surface_text: As in the present case, admittedly, the firm was dissolved before the order of assessment was made, the said order -was bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm ceases legal existence on dissolution; no statutory machinery under 1953 Act permits assessment of dissolved firm despite pre-dissolution turnover.

holdings.text: a firm is an independent assessable unit for the purposes of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: If we read the expression firm in substitution of the word dealer, it will be apparent that a firm is an independent assessable unit for the purposes of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of 'dealer' in S.2(d) includes firm as distinct from person or HUF; same treatment as under Income-tax Act S.3.

holdings.text: unless there is a statutory provision permitting the assessment of a dissolved firm, there is no longer any scope for assessing the firm which ceased to have a legal existence.

anchor.surface_text: If that be so, on dissolution, the firm ceases to be be a legal entity. Thereafter, on principle, unless there is a statutory provision permitting the assessment of a dissolved firm, there is number-longer any scope for assessing the firm which ceased to have a legal existence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm treated as legal entity for tax purposes only while existing; dissolution ends entity status absent express statutory revival for assessment.

holdings.text: we cannot discover any distinction in the matter of assessability of a dissolved firm between a case where the proceedings were initiated before and that after the said dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: Further, we cannot discover any distinction in the matter of assessability of a dissolved firm between a case where the proceedings were initiated before and that after the said dissolution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lost entity status precludes assessment regardless of timing of proceedings initiation; no statutory basis for distinction.

holdings.text: such a power [to assess dissolved firm] cannot be gathered by necessary implication from the other provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether such a power can be gathered by necessary implication from the other provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict fiscal construction; no express provision, no implication from S.16, S.17, Rule 40 or registration requirements.

holdings.text: Section 16... does not expressly state that a dealer, if it happens to be a firm, continues to have legal existence even if it has ceased to be a firm.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16, so far as is relevant to the present enquiry, only says that if a dealer discontinues his business, it shall within the prescribed time inform the prescribed authority accordingly. This section does number expressly state that a dealer, if it happens to be a firm, companytinues to have legal existence even if it has ceased to be a firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.16 merely administrative notice requirement; no implication of continued entity or assessment power post-dissolution.

holdings.text: r. 40... only imposes a joint and several liability on the dealer and its partners for the payment of tax... It does not provide for a case of the dissolution of a firm and the assessment of the dissolved firm.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does r. 40 of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Rules, 1949, carry the matter further. It only imposes a joint and several liability on the dealer and its partners for the payment of tax penalty or any amount due under the Act or the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule addresses payment liability of partners, distinguishes from power to assess non-existent firm entity.

holdings.text: There is... a lacuna in the Act, which was filled up later on by an amending Act but the said Amending Act... is not retrospective in operation.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, a lacuna in the Act, which was filled up later on by an amending Act but the said Amending Act, it is companyceded, is number retrospective in operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1953 Act lacks provision for dissolved firm assessment; later amendment non-retrospective confirms original gap.

holdings.text: we cannot accept the validity of the reasons given in the said judgments for maintaining an assessment on a dissolved firm

anchor.surface_text: All these decisions... were overburdened with the companysequences of a companytrary companystruction on the incidence of taxation and also by their mixing up the question of the statutory power of assessing a dissolved firm with the liability of the partners thereof to pay the tax so assessed on the firm before dissolution. For the reasons we have already given earlier, we cannot accept the validity of the reasons given in the said judgments for maintaining an assessment ,on a dissolved firm, whether the proceedings were initiated before or after the firm was dissolved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Various High Court decisions erroneous for conflating assessment power with partners' payment liability and fearing revenue loss; strict construction prevails.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Act contains an express provision for assessing a dissolved firm.

anchor.surface_text: These two decisions are of numberhelp to the Revenue in the present case. Indeed, in a sense they are against it. The Income-tax Act companytains an express provision for assessing a dissolved firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes sales tax Act lacking S.44-like machinery from Income-tax Act; supports no-implied-power conclusion.

precedents.citation: Lalji v. The Assistant Commissioner, Salestax, Raipur  2

anchor.surface_text: The Madhya Pradesh High Court in Lalji v. The Assistant Commissioner, Salestax, Raipur  2   relied upon S. 17 of the C.P. and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, similar to S. 16 of the present Act, to sustain the companytinuity of a firm as a legal entity till a numberice companytemplated by that section was given.

precedents.case_name: Lalji v. Assistant Commissioner, Sales Tax, Raipur
precedents.cited_proposition: Firm continues as legal entity till notice under sales tax provision given

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court in R. D. Fernandes in re 1  relied upon the provisions of the Partnership Act to reach the desired end.

precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of Partnership Act allow assessment after dissolution

precedents.citation: Khushi Ram Behari Lal Co. v. The Assessing Authority Sangrur  4

anchor.surface_text: The Punjab High Court in Khushi Ram Behari Lal Co. v. The Assessing Authority Sangrur  4   distinguished the Full Bench decision, which is the subject matter of the present appeal before us, on the ground that the dissolution of the firm in the case before it was long after the assessment proceedings were initiated.

precedents.case_name: Khushi Ram Behari Lal Co. v. Assessing Authority Sangrur
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessment proceedings initiated before dissolution can continue; distinguished on facts

precedents.citation: R. Poonuswami Gramani v The Collector of Chingleput District 1

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court in R. Poonuswami Gramani v The Collector of Chingleput District 1  followed the earlier decision of that Court and it does number companytain any reasoning on the question.

precedents.case_name: R. Poonuswami Gramani v. Collector of Chingleput District
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed earlier decision sustaining assessment after dissolution

precedents.citation: Bankatlal Badruka v. The, State of Bombay  1

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court in Bankatlal Badruka v. The, State of Bombay  1 based its companyclusion only on the circumstance that the numberice of dissolution under r. 35 of the Hyderabad General Sales Tax Rules 1950, was number given before the assessment.

precedents.case_name: Bankatlal Badruka v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessment valid if no notice of dissolution given before assessment

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Sales- tax, Orissa v. Aurbinde Auto Service 7

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa High Court in Commissioner of Sales- tax, Orissa v. Aurbinde Auto Service 7  also sustained the assessment after dissolution inter alia, on the ground that numbernotice of dissolution was given under s. 18  b  of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax, Orissa v. Aurbinde Auto Service
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessment after dissolution valid if no notice given and based on specific provision like IT Act s.44

precedents.citation: C. A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in C. A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam 1 , speaking through Shah, J., held that S. 44 of the Income-tax Act set up a machinery for assessing the tax liability of firms which have discontinued their business.

precedents.case_name: C.A. Abraham v. Income-tax Officer, Kottayam
precedents.cited_proposition: S. 44 of the Income-tax Act sets up machinery for assessing tax liability of firms which have discontinued business
precedents.cited_holding: S. 44 sets up a machinery for assessing the tax liability of firms which have discontinued their business

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V. Angidi Chettiar 2

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by this Court again in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V. Angidi Chettiar 2 . These two decisions are of numberhelp to the Revenue in the present case.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V. Angidi Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed the holding in C.A. Abraham on S.44 of Income-tax Act for assessing discontinued firms

anchor.surface_text: Section 16, so far as is relevant to the present enquiry, only says that if a dealer discontinues his business, it shall within the prescribed time inform the prescribed authority accordingly.
